biogHist.abstract: A self-taught anthropologist, Daisy Bates conducted fieldwork amongst several Indigenous nations in western and southern Australia. She supported herself largely by writing articles for urban newspapers on such topics as 'native cannibalism' and the 'doomed' fate of Indigenous peoples. Bates also published her work on Indigenous kinship systems, marriage laws, language and religion in books and articles. She was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) for Aboriginal welfare work in 1934.
biogHist.p: Daisy May Bates first arrived in Australia in 1884 and worked as a governess in Berry, New South Wales from 1884-1885. She worked on the Review of Reviews in London, 1894-1899, gaining expertise in journalism.

From 1899-1900 she was at the Trappist mission, Beagle Bay, north of Broome and in 1904 was appointed by the Western Australian government to research the tribes of the State. Bates was a member of an expedition led by A.R. Radcliffe-Brown to study the social anthropology of Aboriginal people of north-west Australia in 1910.

Over more than twenty years Bates camped at several locations in South Australia and Western Australia; Eucla, 1912-1914; near Yalata, 1915-1918; and near Ooldea, 1918-1934; She was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) for Aboriginal welfare work on January 1, 1934. She was a member of the British Royal Anthropological Institute and the Australasian Anthropological Institute.

Bates wrote her autobiography 'My natives and I' in a tent at Pyap, South Australia, 1935-1940. This was serialised in The Adelaide Advertiser and later edited and published as The Passing of the Aborigines in 1938. Her articles appeared in several newspapers, including The Catholic Record, The Western Mail, The Adelaide Advertiser, and The Children's Newspaper.
She lived in Wynbring, east of Ooldea, South Australia from 1941 until old age and failing health led her to return to Adelaide in 1945, where she remained until her death in 1951.

Bates is remembered in an ambivalent light by Indigenous and non-Indigenous folk-lore, and has been represented in children's literature, theatre, film and opera. According to the Australian Dictionary of Biography, Bates was given the affectionate name 'Kabbarli', meaning 'grandmotherly person'; the Encyclopaedia of Aboriginal Australia records that Anangu people living at Yalata have referred to Bates as 'Daiji Bate mamu' ('mamu' meaning ghost or devil) and as 'that poor old lady at Ooldea.'

descriptiveNote.p: Margaret Sutherland's one-act opera 'The Young Kabbarli' was based on an incident from the life of Daisy Bates

archref.abstract: Letters to John Mathew c1905-13 [MS 9290]. 120 letters to W.P. Hurst 1918-46, and other papers dealing with her work with Australian Aborigines [MS 7987].

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Daisy May Bates - Records

archref.repository: State Library of South Australia, Mortlock Library of South Australiana
archref.abstract: 93 letters to Miss Winifred Howie, Adelaide. 19 letters to Mr and Mrs Micken. Overall dates c1900-51.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Daisy May Bates - Records

archref.repository: Mitchell and Dixson Libraries Manuscripts Collection, State Library of New South Wales
archref.abstract: Correspondence with Georgina King, W.H. Gill, J.F. Thomas, W.H. Ifould and N. Campbell c1900-51.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Daisy May Bates - Records

archref.abstract: General correspondence, mostly to the South Australian Museum (12 items, Series 1); manuscripts titled 'Cannibalism and Aborigines', 'Inma or tjurungas from Ooldea' (3 items, Series 2); notes and labels relating to ethnographic collection held by the South Australian Museum (5 items, Series 3); native vocabulary (Series 4); newspaper cuttings (1 item, Series 5); glass plate negative (1 item, Series 6); copy negative and print (1 item, Series 7); overall dates c1900-51 [23 items, AA23].

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Papers of Daisy Bates

archref.repository: National Library of Australia Manuscript Collection
archref.abstract: A large collection of diaries, notebooks and fragments of paper arranged under the following headings: origin, geographical distribution, social organisation, initiation ceremonies, totems, religious beliefs and superstitions, myths and legends, food, weapons, art, crafts, diseases, remedies, death and burial, dances, songs, language, grammar and vocabularies, general notes on Aborigines, notebook - various topics, annotated notebooks - scheme of classification, collection of published articles, correspondence, notes, newspaper articles, photographs, records of Native Affairs, maps c1900-51 [8.5 m, MS 365]. Inwards correspondence c1900-1951 [23 items, MS 2300]. Photographs of Daisy Bates are held in the Pictorial Collection. Oral history interview (TRC 160).

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Daisy Bates -Records

archref.repository: JS Battye Library of West Australian History, State Library of Western Australia
archref.abstract: Material in C.S.O. File 4875/10 volume 1, personal and composite file including C.S.O., Aborigines and Statistician's Office files 1904-11 [ACC 1023]. Correspondence with L. Glauert concerning specimens while at Ooldea 1922-1935 [ACC 856A]. Transcripts of collected papers in the National Library of Australia, including anthropological notes and vocabularies of the native language (with card index of contents) [ACC 1212A].
